segments.en: Middle Discourses 134
Lomasakaṅgiya and One Fine Night
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo sakkesu viharati kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya was staying in the Sakyan country at Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.

segments.pli: Atha kho candano devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ nigrodhārāmaṃ obhāsetvā yenāyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho candano devaputto āyasmantaṃ lomasakaṅgiyaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then, late at night, the glorious god Candana, lighting up the entire Banyan Tree Monastery, went up to the Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya, and stood to one side. Standing to one side, he said to Lomasakaṅgiya:
“Mendicant, do you remember the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night?”

segments.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.
segments.en: “No, reverend, I do not.

segments.pli: Tvaṃ panāvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañcā”ti?
segments.en: Do you?”

segments.pli: “Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.
segments.en: “I also do not.

segments.pli: Dhāresi pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattiyo gāthā”ti?
segments.en: But do you remember just the verses on One Fine Night?”

segments.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.
segments.en: “I do not.
Do you?”
“I do.”

segments.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, āvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā”ti?
segments.en: “How do you remember the verses on One Fine Night?”

segments.pli: “Ekamidaṃ, bhikkhu, samayaṃ bhagavā devesu tāvatiṃsesu viharati pāricchattakamūle paṇḍukambalasilāyaṃ.
segments.en: “This one time, the Buddha was staying among the gods of the Thirty-Three at the root of the Shady Orchard Tree on the stone spread with a cream rug.

segments.pli: Tatra bhagavā devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsi:
segments.en: There he taught the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night to the gods of the Thirty-Three:
‘Don’t run back to the past,
don’t hope for the future.
What’s past is left behind;
the future has not arrived;
and phenomena in the present
are clearly seen in every case.
Knowing this, foster it—
unfaltering, unshakable.
Today’s the day to keenly work—
who knows, tomorrow may bring death!
For there is no bargain to be struck
with Death and his mighty hordes.
The peaceful sage explained it’s those
who keenly meditate like this,
tireless all night and day,
who truly have that one fine night.’

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.
segments.en: That’s how I remember the verses of One Fine Night.

segments.pli: Uggaṇhāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;
segments.en: Learn the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine Night, mendicant,

segments.pli: pariyāpuṇāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;
segments.en: memorize it,

segments.pli: dhārehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.
segments.en: and remember it.

segments.pli: Atthasaṃhito, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddeso ca vibhaṅgo ca ādibrahmacariyako”ti.
segments.en: It is beneficial and relates to the fundamentals of the spiritual life.”
That’s what the god Candana said
before vanishing right there.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo tassā rattiyā accayena senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
segments.en: Then Lomasakaṅgiya set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sāvatthī.

segments.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena sāvatthi jetavanaṃ anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāmo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Eventually he came to Sāvatthī and Jeta’s Grove. He went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he added:

segments.pli: “Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ sakkesu viharāmi kapilavatthusmiṃ nigrodhārāme.

Atha kho, bhante, aññataro devaputto abhikkantāya rattiyā abhikkantavaṇṇo kevalakappaṃ nigrodhārāmaṃ obhāsetvā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho, bhante, so devaputto maṃ etadavoca:
Evaṃ vutte, ahaṃ, bhante, taṃ devaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
‘na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.
Tvaṃ panāvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañcā’ti?
‘Ahampi kho, bhikkhu, na dhāremi bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.
Dhāresi pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattiyo gāthā’ti?
‘Na kho ahaṃ, āvuso, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.
‘Yathā kathaṃ pana tvaṃ, āvuso, dhāresi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā’ti?
‘Ekamidaṃ, bhikkhu, samayaṃ bhagavā devesu tāvatiṃsesu viharati pāricchattakamūle paṇḍukambalasilāyaṃ.
Tatra kho bhagavā devānaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca abhāsi:
Evaṃ kho ahaṃ, bhikkhu, dhāremi bhaddekarattiyo gāthā.
Uggaṇhāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;
pariyāpuṇāhi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca;
dhārehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca.
Atthasaṃhito, bhikkhu, bhaddekarattassa uddeso ca vibhaṅgo ca ādibrahmacariyako’ti.
Sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā bhaddekarattassa uddesañca vibhaṅgañca desetū”ti.
segments.en: “Sir, please teach me the recitation passage and analysis of One Fine night.”
“But mendicant, do you know that god?”

segments.pli: “Na kho ahaṃ, bhante, jānāmi taṃ devaputtan”ti.
segments.en: “I do not, sir.”
“That god was named Candana.

segments.pli: Candano, bhikkhu, devaputto aṭṭhiṃ katvā manasikatvā sabbacetasā samannāharitvā ohitasoto dhammaṃ suṇāti.
segments.en: Candana pays heed, pays attention, engages wholeheartedly, and lends an ear to the teaching.

segments.pli: Tena hi, bhikkhu, suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
segments.en: Well then, mendicant, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo bhagavato paccassosi.
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” Lomasakaṅgiya replied.
The Buddha said this:
“Don’t run back to the past,
don’t hope for the future.
What’s past is left behind;
the future has not arrived;
and phenomena in the present
are clearly seen in every case.
Knowing this, foster it—
unfaltering, unshakable.
Today’s the day to keenly work—
who knows, tomorrow may bring death!
For there is no bargain to be struck
with Death and his mighty hordes.
The peaceful sage explained it’s those
who keenly meditate like this,
tireless all night and day,
who truly have that one fine night.
And how do you run back to the past? …”
(And the Buddha repeated the analysis as in MN 131.)

segments.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhu, paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati … pe …
evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, paccuppannesu dhammesu saṃhīrati.
Kathañca, bhikkhu, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati … pe …
evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, paccuppannesu dhammesu na saṃhīrati.

segments.en: That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano āyasmā lomasakaṅgiyo bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
segments.en: Satisfied, Venerable Lomasakaṅgiya was happy with what the Buddha said.

suttaplex.blurb: A monk who does not know the verses from MN 131 is encouraged by a deity to learn them.
